results.title: Cameraman
results.creator_credit: Survival Anglia, Colin Willock and Colin Edlred
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival Anglia Wildlife Series”.
Filming wildlife in exotic locations may sound like a glamourous occupation but, in fact, it is frequently fraught with danger and demands nerve and ice-cool courage. This film reveals the reality, following the trials, hardship, enjoyment and successes of award-winning cameraman Dieter Plage. In the course of his many assignments, Dieter has been run over by an elephant, charged at by a huge male gorilla and had a face-to-face encounter with a tiger. Whether home for several months is a tent in a jungle, a swamp on a mountainside or a remote tropical island, Deiter is always accompanied by his wife Mary who takes care of everything else, leaving her husband free to film his magnificent shots! Some of the unique sequences shown include Rangers rounding up elephants, relocating endangered antelopes and warthogs chasing cheetas!

results.title: Camera three: a video event parts I and II
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
In the Spring of 1974, Merrill Brockway produced two half hour programs featuring Merce Cunningham and his company. The programs were only aired twice that year and were not seen again for twenty-five years. These two programs contain important archival material from the early 1960s and 1970s. Excerpts of performances of “Winterbranch”, “Second Hand”, Sounddance”, “TV Rerun”, “Changing Steps”, “Landrover”, and “Signals are included. Throughout the programs, Cunningham discusses his ideas and approach to dancing. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by Christian Wolff. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Camera natura
results.creator_credit: Camera Natura, Australian Film Commission, John Cruthers and Ross Gibson
results.brief_description: A film about the Australian landscape as portrayed in the myths, maps, painting, writing, photography and cinema of white Australians. The video traces the developing image of the continent as it has been represented over 200 years, from the anguish of the convicted painter Thomas Watling, to the technologies of cinema and aerial photography. Written by Ross Gibson, cinematography by Ray Argall, animation by Lee Whitmore. Voices supplied by Stephen Bisley, Susan Dermody, Vivienne Garrett. Contains some black and white sequences.

results.title: Camera makes whoopee
results.brief_description: Cinematic variations on the subject of the Glasgow School of Art Christmas Ball, 1934, using mixed techniques, including animated objects, optical effects, and live action. Made while Norman McLaren was a student there. No soundtrack.

results.title: Camera magic: the art of special effects
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films, Paul Burnford and Jerry Samuelson
results.brief_description: Demonstrates a variety of camera techniques which can be used to produce special effects with an ordinary 16mm or 8mm motion picture camera without employing special equipment. Shows rotation in space, multiple images, upside down and reverse action, instant appearance and disappearance of objects and people and fast and slow motion. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Camera
results.creator_credit: BBC, Harris Watts and Mike Crisp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On camera: the BBC video production course”.
Consist of four parts: 1. The “Camera and the eye”. Shows the difficulties faced by the camera lens as compared by the eye and notes the advantages of the camera. 2. “Lenses and apertures”. Explains focal length, angle of view, depth of field, aperture openings, the times 2 extender and the gain switch. 3. “Short sizes and camera moves”. Explains basic terminology - such as pan, tilt, depress, track and zoom. 4. “Crossing the line” Shows how to mantain continuity of direction to avoid confusing the viewer.

results.title: Camera
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Associates, Tim Barr and Bruce A. Block
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Uses interviews with cinematographers including Lazlo Kovacs, Lee Garmes and James Crabe to explain the major points of motion picture photography and cameras. Defines and explains many techniques including dolly shots, lenses, camera movement, film speeds and camera focus.

results.title: Camels and the Pitjantjara
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, Curtis Levy and Roger Sandall
results.brief_description: Shows the daily life of nomadic Central Australian Aborigines of the Pitjantjara tribe who have acquired camels, guns and other modern equipment. Shows the capture of a wild camel and travels in the MacDonnell Range hunting rabbits and living off the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, Curtis Levy and Roger Sandall

results.title: Camelot
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Jack L. Warner and Joshua Logan
results.brief_description: Adapted from the very successful Broadway show, “Camelot” features songs from the renowned songwriting team of Lerner and Loewe. Starring Richard Harris, Vanessa Redgrave, Franco Nero, David Hemmings and Lionel Jeffries, it tells of the tragic romantic triangle between Arthur, Guinevere and Sir Lancelot.
